text: hey everybody today I'm super excited to
share with you one of my favorite
recipes for icebox cookies
not only are icebox cookies rich and
buttery there are quick holiday baked
ahead and the variations are endless
[Music]
how do you make it well all you really
need are four basic ingredients and then
you can customize it so in front of me
here I have a food processor with two
sticks of unsalted butter now the butter
here is softened and to that I'm going
to add 3/4 of a cup of confectioner's
sugar confectioner sugar is going to add
the sweetness we need here and to that
I'm going to add one and a half
teaspoons of coarse salt and it's really
important when you're baking to use salt
because it does add that extra element
it elevates the cookie we need 2 and 1/3
cups of all-purpose flour and this is of
course it's spooned and leveled always
use your measuring cups whenever your
baking those 4 ingredients now you can
customize in any way you'd like and
today I'm using dried cherries so I have
3 quarters of a cup these are coarsely
chopped dried cherries you can see what
they look like right here you could use
anything though you could add 3/4 of a
cup of it nuts dried fruits apricots I
have in front of me you can make
chocolate my dad loves chocolate icebox
cookies so 3/4 of a cup of bittersweet
chocolate and a little bit of cocoa
powder to replace the flour in your
batter will give it a nice rich dark
color pistachios are really nice around
the holiday season you can get that
green and then the red from the cherries
golden raisins any of your favorite
fruits or nuts you can add in to this
recipe and make it your own so I'm going
to add that in right here and then all
you do is you pulse this together until
it's one cohesive dough it's super
simple
so this looks like it's nicely combined
still need to work it together a little
bit so I'm going to dump this out onto
my work surface and icebox cookies
they're very similar to shortbread
cookies in that they have a high ratio
of fat now icebox cookies get their name
because they're typically made and
stored in the refrigerator before
they're sliced and used and that's also
a really great thing with this recipe
too because you can make this in advance
you can stick it in your freezer which
is really great this dough will last in
the freezer for about three months so
you can get a head start on your holiday
baking now to shape this into a nice
rounded shape I'm gonna use a piece of
parchment to start so take the dough and
what you're gonna do is you're just
gonna wrap the parchment paper around
the dough kind of wrapping it and then I
like to take a ruler something that's
long and has a flat edge and you can
really use the ruler here place it
firmly down at the base right like how I
have it and then pull the bottom sheet
of parchment paper away from you and
what this does is it compresses the
dough into a nice cylindrical shape a
nice rounded shape and it squeezes out
any air pockets that the dough might
have isn't it cool you can see how it's
really starting to get that nice rounded
shape so now what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna transfer this to a piece of
plastic wrap and this has to rest in the
refrigerator now for about 30 minutes
plastic wrap this so that the the dough
doesn't dry out in your refrigerator you
want to make sure that you really seal
those ends and now to keep a nice
rounded shape while it rests in the
refrigerator so it doesn't flatten out
on the bottom I like to use a paper
towel roll all you need to do quick
trick here is to slice it down the
center to cut it down the center with a
pair of scissors just open this guy up
and what you have here is a nice cradle
for your dough in the refrigerator so
that while it's chilling it doesn't
flatten out on that bottom side it will
keep a nice rounded shape so into the
refrigerator for about 30 minutes until
it's pretty firm and then we're ready to
slice bake and then enjoy so the dough
has been in the refrigerator for about
30 minutes it's pretty firm which is
what you want it to be you don't want it
to be so cold and so hard that when you
slice it with a knife that it kind of
shatters or crumbles into pieces so give
it maybe five minutes out on the counter
before you are ready to slice and bake
so I have my oven preheated to 350
degrees depending on how many cookies
you want to bake if you're gonna do a
couple batches make sure that your racks
in your oven are in the upper and lower
third but if you're only making one tray
of cookies that bake in the middle of
the oven so I'm gonna remove the plastic
wrap here you can see how nice the shape
has stayed because of that cradle that
we created and now using a sharp knife
something that has a thinner blade you
don't want to use a chef's knife hear
anything wide you want to cut your
cookies into quarter-inch rounds see how
nice and round that shape is and that's
even without a cookie cutter isn't that
great so now for something a little
special which is kind of nice for around
the holidays and kids usually like it
I'm gonna embellish the sides with a
little bit of sanding sugars so just
kind of roll the cookie disk around in a
bowl of sanding sugar now if you didn't
have sanding sugar you could totally use
granulated sugar you could use turbinado
sugar if you wanted to get real crazy
and you're doing this with your kids you
could certainly use a colored sugar that
would be fun too and then you're just
gonna repeat this process cutting off as
many cookies as you need garnishing with
sugar if you'd like so there you go
these are going into the oven again 15
to 18 minutes at 350 degrees until
they're a nice dark golden brown color
wrap up the rest of your dough and put
it back in the fridge or the freezer for
the next time so the icebox cookies
they're out of the oven they've cooled
completely guys I mean what's better
than a cookie around the holiday season
four ingredients plus whatever mix-ins
you want to add in
and as always guys enjoy happy holidays
